grounding: Recent developments in language modeling have enabled large text encoders to derive a wealth of linguistic information from raw text corpora without supervision. Their success across natural language processing (NLP) tasks has called into question the role of man-made computational resources, such as verb lexicons, in supporting modern NLP. Still, probing analyses have concurrently exposed the limitations of the knowledge possessed by the large neural architectures, revealing them to be clever task solvers rather than self-taught linguists. Can human-designed lexical resources still help fill their knowledge gaps? Focusing on verb classification, we discuss approaches to generating verb classes multilingually and weigh the relative benefits of undertaking expensive lexicographic work and outsourcing the task to untrained native speakers. Then, we consider the evidence for the utility of augmenting pretrained language models with external verb knowledge and ponder the ways in which human expertise can continue to benefit multilingual NLP.
generated_text: This study presents a novel approach to verb classification across multiple languages, addressing the challenges of multilingual Natural Language Processing (NLP). We propose a framework that combines knowledge augmentation of neural models with crowdsourced data to create a comprehensive and linguistically diverse verb classification system. Our method leverages pre-trained language models and enhances them with structured linguistic knowledge, while also incorporating human expertise through carefully designed crowdsourcing tasks. We evaluate our approach on a dataset comprising 10 typologically diverse languages, demonstrating significant improvements in verb classification accuracy compared to existing monolingual and cross-lingual baselines. The results highlight the effectiveness of our hybrid approach in capturing nuanced verb semantics across languages, paving the way for more robust multilingual NLP applications. This work contributes to the growing field of multilingual language understanding and offers valuable insights for future research in cross-lingual semantic analysis.
